user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Static(const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list  */
            break;
        }
        if (StaticSym->Module != NULL && strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0)
        {
            /* found matching module name */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
typedef const struct
{
    const char *Name;
    void (*Address)(void);
    const char *Module;
} OS_static_symbol_record_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The single statement OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE; itself does not call any <string.h> functions and therefore does not by itself violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. However, elsewhere in the function strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) is invoked: that call is only guarded against StaticSym->Module being NULL, but ModuleName is not checked. A violation of Rule 21.17 can occur at that strcmp call if ModuleName is NULL or if either pointer does not reference a properly NUL-terminated character array (causing access beyond the object bounds).
